author: Stuart Greer
title: Review: Green Day at Manchester Arena
text:
Green Day at Manchester Arena (Photo: Sean Hansford/MEN) Share Get What's On   Thank you for subscribing!   
At times of civil unease music has always played a central role in channelling and galvanising protest. 
Green Day to some extent have made a career out it, turning their outrage of America’s invasion of Iraq in 2003 and the their fury at President George W. Bush into a concept album, American Idiot, then, rather bizarrely, into a hit Broadway musical. 
Now after an eight year hiatus of sorts, the Republicans are back in charge. It’s almost like American Idiot wasn’t a reaction but a forecast. 
Frontman Billie Joe Armstrong came to the right place if he wanted solidarity against Trump. Only a few weeks ago the city saw a huge protest against the divisive rhetoric of the new so-called Leader of the Free World. 
“Donald Trump is not my president,” Armstrong spits after finishing his own take on the protest song ‘Holiday’, “He will be gone soon. We will not be divided.” 
The roar from the vibrant crowd agreed with the sentiment. Read More Green Day fans at Manchester Arena (Photo: Sean Hansford/MEN) Read More Sounds From The Other City 2017 announces line up - how to get tickets 
It is just one of many times that the fervent audience bellowed their approval for the power punk trio, who proved that they are more relevant than ever. 
They bounded onto the stage at 8pm on the dot like a group of musicians half their age and launched into ‘Know Your Enemy’ and ‘Bang Bang’, Armstrong, with his jet black mop, bassist Mike Dirnt in his iconic bleached blonde barnet and the drummer Tré Cool with his elaborate turquoise Mohican. 
For two and half hours the trio gave a blistering performance of almost 30 songs. One of the stand outs was ‘Revolution Radio’, the title track from their 12th album released last autumn, which was elevated with a raucous pyrotechnics display. 
There was a welcome lull for the anthemic ‘Boulevard of Broken Dreams’ before the band dusted of a few classics ‘Longview’ and ‘When I Come Around’ from 1994, songs written before half of the audience were probably born, judging on the demographic in the sweaty, bruising mosh pit. 
While there was a lot of anger and outrage from Armstrong, there was also one hell of a party - and fancy dress. 
With the band’s keyboardist Jason Freese taking up the saxophone the crowd caught their breath with an interlude involving a series of unexpected covers including a medley with George Michael’s ‘Careless Whisper’, The Isley Brothers’ ‘Shout’ and Monty Pythons’ ‘Always Look on the bright side of life’. Read More Stormzy announces Manchester date on UK tour - how to buy tickets (Photo: Sean Hansford/MEN) 
Normal service was resumed with the singalong ‘Breathing on my own’ and ‘American Idiot’ which put the audience into one final frenzy. 
It’s not all big and brash, there are some nice moments where Armstrong’s songwriting prowess come to the fore. In ‘Are We The Waiting’ Armstrong manages to conjure an intimate moment amid thousands or adoring fans and the show ends with a nostalgic version of ‘Good Riddance (Time of your life)’. There are also three brilliant moment when fans are welcomed onto the stage to perform with the band, the most notable of which was the starstruck girl who proved herself to be a kick-ass guitarist. 
It has been more than 30 years since Green Day pogoed onto the punk rock scene. 85 million record sales later and the punk has watered down somewhat. Thankfully the rock hasn’t. And in Trump it seems they’ve found another reason to keep cranking it up. Read More
